CRT: Over 15,000:1Display "Technology Shoot-Out: Comparing CRT, LCD, Plasma and DLP Displays", Dr. Raymond M. Soneira, DisplayMate Technologies website
OLED: ∞  "Inf:1"language=en-US Unable to be calculated as black levels are zero.

LCD: 200–4000cd/m²{{Cite web|title=Peak Brightness of TVs: Max luminosity and HDR highlights|url=

CRT: 24-bit per pixel resolution, offers better resolution for grayscale
LCD: 6 to 10-bit per subpixel panels,language=en smaller dot pitch, better detailCOP 3502 Introduction to Computer Science
OLED: 8 to 10-bit per subpixel, with some HDR models capable of 12-bit per subpixel.

CRT: 0.01ms to less than 1µs"An investigation of the test process used to date for determining the response time of an LCD monitor, known as input lag – Thomas Thiemann at prad.de"
LCD: 1–8ms typical (according to manufacturer data), older units could be as slow as 35ms"LCD Monitors, TVs: Electronics – Microcenter", Scroll down and look at the bar on the left to see the number of monitors they offer that have certain specifications. Retrieved April 2013
Plasma: Typically less than 0.001ms, as low as 0.00001ms
OLED: Estimates varying from under 0.01ms to as low as 0.001ms.

CRT: 60–85fps typically, some CRTs can go even higher (200fps at reduced resolution),internally, display refreshed at input frame rate speed
LCD: 60fps typically, gaming monitors can do up to 240fps,internally, display refreshed at up to 240HzHDTV Refresh Rates Explained: 60Hz, 120Hz, and Beyond, Retrieved April 2013
Plasma: 60fps typically, some can do 120fps,internally, display refreshed at e.g. 480 or 600Hz"What is 600Hz Sub Field Drive?", Retrieved April 2013

CRT: Perceptible on lower refresh rates (60Hz and below)
LCD: Depends, in 2013 most LCDs used PWM (strobing) to dim the backlightExplanation of why pulse width modulated backlighting is used, and its side-effects, "Pulse Width Modulation on LCD monitors", TFT Central. Retrieved June 2012. However, since then many flicker free LCD computer monitors were introduced. Flicker Free Monitor Database on tftcentral.co.uk
Plasma: Does not normally occur due to high refresh rate.How Do Plasma TVs Create No Flicker?
OLED: Does not normally occur at 100% brightness level. At levels below 100% flicker often occurs with frequencies between 60 and 255hz, since often pulse-width modulation is used to dim OLED screens.

Technology: Risk of image persistence or burn-in

CRT: HighTom's Hardware: Power Consumption Benchmark Results for CRT versus TFT LCD "Benchmark Results: Different Brightness Testing"
Plasma: Varies with brightness but usually higher than LCDPlasma vs LCD vs LED - Digital Direct
OLED: Varies based on image brightness and color. For the majority of images it will consume 60–80% of the power of an LCD.  OLED displays use 40% of the power of an LCD displaying an image that is primarily black as they lack the need for a backlight, while OLED can use more than three times as much power to display a mostly white image compared to an LCD.

CRT: Sensitive to ambient magnetic fields, which can adversely affect convergence and color purity.
LCD: Prone to malfunctions on both low (below -4°F/-20°C) or high (above 45°C/113°F) temperaturesDoes Altitude or Temperature Affect LCD Monitors?
Plasma: High altitude pressure difference may cause poor function or buzzing noisesPlasmaTVBuyingGuide.com Plasma TVs at Altitude

CRT: Can emit a small amount of X-ray radiation.
Plasma: Emits strong radio frequency electromagnetic radiationeham Amateur Radio Forum "Plasma TV – Mother of All RFI Producers", Retrieved April 2013

LCD: Up to 108" (2.78 m) title=Sharp to Introduce World's Largest*1 108-Inch LCD Monitor for Commercial Applications, Now Accepting Orders
Plasma: Up to 150" (3.8 m) title=6ft by 150 inchesSnd and that's just the TV

CRT: Hazardous to repair or service due to high-voltage, requires skilled convergence calibration and adjustments for geographic location changes. Glass display tube is evacuated and carries risk of implosion if improperly handled.
LCD: Risky and expensive to repair due to complexity of the display, units with mercury lamps are a minor environmental health hazard
Plasma: Screen itself cannot be repaired if the gas used to generate images leaksPlasma Repair Answers

CRT: No native resolution. Currently, the only display technology capable of multi-syncing (displaying different resolutions and refresh rates without the need for scaling).Native Resolution - AfterDawn: Glossary of technology terms & acronyms Display lag is extremely low due to its nature, which does not have the ability to store image data before output, unlike LCDs, plasma displays and OLED displays. Extremely bulky and heavy construction in comparison to other display technologies. Large displays would be unsuitable for wall mounting. New models are no longer produced.
LCD: The LCD grid can mask effects of spatial and grayscale quantization, creating the illusion of higher image quality.  M. d'Zmura, T. P. Janice Shen, Wei Wu, Homer Chen, and Marius Vassiliou (1998), "Contrast Gain Control for Color Image Quality," IS&T/SPIE Conference on Human Vision and Electronic Imaging III, San Jose, California, January 1998, SPIE Vol. 3299, 194–201.  Is the cheapest display technology currently produced, with some entry-level models selling for less than $100.
Plasma: Screen-door effects are more noticeable than LCD when up close, or on larger sizes.  New models are no longer produced.
OLED: Coloured sub-pixels may age at different rates, leading to a colour shift. Sensitive to UV light from direct sunlight. Is considered the highest quality but also the most expensive display technology currently produced, with products rarely being available for less than $1000.
